Alice in Wonderland (2010) - Nostalgia C.Title: Alice in Wonderland (2010) - Nostalgia Critic
Alice in Wonderland (2010) - Nostalgia C.Description:
Tim Burton! The Nostalgia Critic reviews 2010's Alice in Wonderland.  
Originally aired on 3/11/2014.

Alice in Wonderland is a 2010 American period adventure fantasy film directed by Tim Burton from a screenplay written by Linda Woolverton and produced by Walt Disney Pictures. The film stars Mia Wasikowska in the title role, with Johnny Depp, Anne Hathaway, Helena Bonham Carter, Crispin Glover, and Matt Lucas, while featuring the voices of Alan Rickman, Stephen Fry, Michael Sheen, and Timothy Spall. A live-action adaptation and re-imagining of Lewis Carroll's works, the film follows Alice Kingsleigh, a nineteen-year-old who accidentally falls down a rabbit hole, returns to Underland and alongside the Mad Hatter, helps restore the White Queen to her throne by fighting against the Red Queen and her Jabberwocky, a dragon that terrorizes Underland's inhabitants.

Comments.text: Fun fact, in Sweden, the original movie was called Alice i Underlandet (Alice in the Underland), and they called it Underland, because in Swedish, "Under" means wonder. When watching this movie for the first time I got so shocked when they said Underland, because it's called that in Swedish ( though it's pronounced another way "Onderland")

Comments.author: @P-C-Principle
Comments.text: Mercury poisoning doesn’t make you talk in different accents. Depp is very talented but his version of the mad hatter is literally the polar opposite of his cartoon counterpart. He doesn’t sound like he’s gone mad at all, he just sounds like someone with trauma and never had anyone around to help them grieve properly, which still wouldn’t cause you to talk in accents. Especially in Wonderland where such things as different accents just don’t exist. He’s actually looks like someone with an extra chromosome and a half. The skit they made in the video is more faithful of the original Alice in Wonderland. I had to rewatch this version to remember just how many arguments me and my siblings had over the first film by Burton. The second one was unanimously hated by all of us than goodness.

Comments.author: @rattlebear25
Comments.text: The reason why no one can fight the Jabberwocky or the Red Queen outside Alice is that despite their powers is this: the movie is based on the two Alice books: Wonderland and Throught the Looking Glass. In fact, Jabberwocky and the Red Queen are villains in the second story and the dragon represents adulthood. Alice fighting the Jabberwocky meaning entering in the adult world, a path that ONLY her can do. That's why no one helps her: Alice must fight alone the adulthood. Also that part "Alice is always being Alice!" When her friends talk about finding the "Right Alice" they mean "The Alice ready to fight the Jabberwocky (Adulthood). The past Alice wasn't ready to grown up and after all here adventures in Wonderland she is finally the right Alice, the one who can finally left childhood and become an adult.

Comments.author: @danielscott5673
Comments.text:
i frickin' hate this film (and the 2016 sequel too). it's an insult to both the book and disney animated film (as walt disney understood the source material better than tim burton). even tim burton himself admitted to not like the book, wow, way to disrespect the lewis carroll fans.

why is the 1951 disney animated film an honest to god straight forward adaptation of the lewis carroll book(s)? they acknowledged it during the film's opening credits! tim burton failed on that for his pos film.

if it's a remake, why is it taking place after the 'supposed events' of both the book and disney animated film? it doesn't make sense as a sequel.
if it's a sequel, why do the characters not look the same as from the disney animated film?
(the dormouse is male in disney animated film, not female, and doesn't even look the same as the 1951 version),
(the mad hatter does not look the same as the 1951 version),
(the cheshire cat doesn't look the same as the 1951 version),
(the dodo bird does not look the same as the 1951 version),
(the red queen's card guards doesn't look the same as their 1951 counterparts),
(there's no red and white queen in the 1951 film, there's only the queen of hearts),
(tweedledee and tweedledum do not look the same as the ones from the 1951 film, as well as ripping off Pugsley's design from Addams Family),
(alice has personality and a clear character (played by kathryn beaumont) than mia wasikowska, who delivers an awful performance, and alice isn't a typical bland feminist action heroine, even ellen ripley would come in and say 'Bitch, fix your personality and stop copying me'),

and on top of it, if it's supposed to be a sequel to 'Alice in Wonderland', then WHY THE FLIPPIN' F#@K IS IT CALLED "ALICE IN WONDERLAND"?!
American McGee's Alice games are true in advertising: both American McGee's Alice and Alice: Madness Returns.
Alice in Wonderland 2010 is a turd with decent visuals in bullsh@t advertising and a corporate stupid sellout.

(mia wasikowska does fine acting in both The Kids Are All Right and Crimson Peak, but in tim burton's film and 2016 sequel, she's bland and awful),

(wonderland is no longer called 'Wonderland' and is instead called 'Underland', which is definitely an inferior name to a surreal fantasy world that celebrates having no sense and logic, as well as this film not only reuses tired chosen one and prophecy cliches, it also rips off both Lord of the Rings and Chronicles of Narnia, even the disney ones of narnia),
(see, surreal nonsensical fantasy doesn't go hand-to-hand with epic fantasy, one is not like the other).

and the scene of alan rickman (r.i.p., dude) telling mia's 'Alice' of her past and given us a flashback, the movie just literally shoot itself in the foot and HUGELY destroyed the film itself. wow, way to MAJORLY pissed us off.

i don't care that this movie made 1 billion dollars, by giving attention to it, praise to it and even liking it, you showed of encouraging disney to giving us live action remakes that are hugely inferior to their animated counterparts.

American McGee does a better job with Alice in Wonderland than tim burton. even McGee isn't a fan of this film.

the 2009 Alice miniseries on syfy channel is an honest reimagining of Alice in Wonderland than tim burton's film.

the 1999 hallmark Alice in Wonderland miniseries with gene wilder and martin short is a better live action adaptation than tim burton's film.

Several reviews criticized the decision to turn Alice into a "colonialist entrepreneur" at the end of the film setting sail for China. Given Britain's role in the First and Second Opium Wars during the Victorian era and the foreign domination of China through "unequal treaties", China expert Kevin Slaten writes, "Not only is it troubling imagery, for a female role model in a Disney movie, but it's also a celebration of the exploitation that China suffered for a century."

as doug said: CARE BEARS IN WONDERLAND IS A BETTER ADAPTATION THAN THIS!

and this film and its 2016 sequel couldn't decide if they wanted to be direct followups, standalone films or both. these tim burton films just straight up sucks!

F#@K! THIS! MOVIE!!! AND IT'S 2016 SEQUEL TOO!!!

Comments.author: @TheIllusiveMan11
Comments.text: 25:24 - That is a fundamental misunderstanding of Wonderland. Despite what people think, Wonderland isn't a place of complete nonsense without any logic to it at all. In fact, Wonderland has a clearly defined set of rules and logic to the world. The insanity comes from the fact these rules don't align with our own, they're like the rules in a kid's game or a dream. But there are still rules. So a guy showing up to introduce rules and laws to Wonderland would be pointless because it already has those.

Comments.author: @rits7995
Comments.text:
Something kind of struck me with the last segment with Doug's Burton Corner. Kid Doug looking up to Tim who has done a lot of great movies with a couple stinkers here and there is strikingly close to how a decent amount of YouTubers grew up admiring Nostalgia Critic but ended up flipping out over The Wall review, claiming NC never had good takes or has lost his touch. There were dozens of videos critiquing his review, thousands of hate comments from former fans, and still to this day, it is seen as a "mark" on NC's record. 
But after all that, Doug continues to make great and funny Nostalgia Critic videos every week and his reviews get more creative as time goes on.  If a director can get a second chance (or third or fourth chance) after making a bad movie, so can YouTubers after a subpar or controversial video. Thanks for the awesome videos and helping me get through my university studies!
